results.title: The Youngest WAAAF in the service
results.creator_credit: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For Jean Williamson, her time at the Women’s Auxiliary Australian Airforce was new and exciting and, much to her disappointment, short. She joined a few months shy of the end of the war. Still, as she looks back through an album of memories, she reflects fondly on friends made, good times and meeting her husband Noel. She also considers how at that time she wasn’t aware she was an Indigenous Australian. When she found out, she responded by becoming heavily involved in the Indigenous community. Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Sleeping dragon
results.creator_credit: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The attack on the World Trade Centre in September 2001 resonated with veterans like Graham Atkinson, reminding him of his time in Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s. Graham tells of how being in the army taught him strength, respect and a sense of dignity for all. Vietnam was a turning point for this Indigenous Australian. He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Bringing his spirit home
results.creator_credit: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.

results.title: Wooden chains
results.creator_credit: Jim Willox, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: He would whittle away at scraps of wood for hours, lost in the quiet moments of himself, perhaps trying to make sense of the war, we’ll never know. A son’s reflection on the life of his father, a veteran from World War I, who returned both psychologically and physically scarred but would never share these scars with the rest of his family, choosing to spend his later years in quiet and solitary contemplation. Jim Willox and his family can only guess at the trauma that bellies the whittling his dad so regularly engaged in. A tribute to a war veteran by his son, who will never fully comprehend all he went through.

results.title: Wings
results.creator_credit: Jack McMahon, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jack McMahon wanted to be a pilot for as long as he can remember. When war was declared, he signed up as soon as he could and, unsurprisingly, joined the Air Force. He warmly talks about his time during World War II, the friendships and bonds created and the crucial moments during the war where he needed to step up and take a chance. Despite being told by his instructor that he was going to kill himself, Jack McMahon returned to Australia and was honoured for his services during the Anzac Day football match in 2008.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack McMahon, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling

results.title: Convoy of life
results.creator_credit: Doss Jenkins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Doss Jenkins’ driving instructor was not fond of female drivers and was strict but she passed and soon became part of a long convoy transporting American goods over Australia. The journey was a gruelling and hot 108 weeks on the road, travelling at 50km an hour. Doss reflects on the things that kept her going, the games she played and the friends she made. This group of ladies still have an annual reunion due to the strong bond created by the journey.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Doss Jenkins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: V160777 (Chocos)
results.creator_credit: Bill Goodes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When he signed up as a conscript, Bill Goodes was given the number V160777 and the label Choco. He knew it was given to the conscripts that, like him, fought in New Guinea, but he had no idea what it meant, though he did sense the connotation was negative. He reflects on how he fought like any other soldier, for three years without a break. In New Guinea, he was just like everyone else. But when he returned to Australia to take up life as a dairy farmer, he soon realised that some people just saw him as a Choco. For Bill, none of this has detracted from his contribution to the war effort.

results.title: Come on Bushy
results.creator_credit: Bill Bush, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bill Bush joined the army for a bit of adventure and to escape troubles at home. He fought in Korea, where his skills as a paramedic were also utilised. He continued this work into civilian life. With a mantra of doing what you were told, without complaint, Bill ultimately leads a happy life doing what he loves.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Bush, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Great escape
results.creator_credit: Allen Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: “That day the Americans gave us a fruit cake was a very rare day indeed, as breaks were not on the cards”. A near-miss while relaxing in Tambu Bay, New Guinea right near the end of the war was a turning point in more ways than one. The senselessness of war drove Allen to find his own happiness and sense of meaning when he returned to civilian life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: When the priest came
results.creator_credit: Brianna Smith, Paul Penno, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Paul was taught from an early age to fear the spread of communism. Then the opportunity came to fight it when he was conscripted in the army during the Vietnam war. Initially, it was a lark travelling around Vietnam, visiting villages, but things got serious soon enough. A priest was flown in and soldiers either clung on to their beliefs, or questioned them. Paul’s involvement in the war put him at odds with his father but, having experienced war first-hand, Paul begins to understand why his father felt the way he did.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brianna Smith, Paul Penno, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Paul’s involvement in the war put him at odds with his father but, having experienced war first-hand, Paul begins to understand why his father felt the way he did.
description_for_label: Paul was taught from an early age to fear the spread of communism. Then the opportunity came to fight it when he was conscripted in the army during the Vietnam war. Initially, it was a lark travelling around Vietnam, visiting villages, but things got serious soon enough. A priest was flown in and soldiers either clung on to their beliefs, or questioned them. Paul’s involvement in the war put him at odds with his father but, having experienced war first-hand, Paul begins to understand why his father felt the way he did.
